newsitem.title: BRAZIL: Brazil's FEF fund bill faces 1st Congress vote Wed.
newsitem.headline: Brazil's FEF fund bill faces 1st Congress vote Wed.

text.p: A bill extending Brazil's Fiscal Stabilization Fund (FEF), a key fiscal tool which allows the government to sidestep constitutional rules on spending, faces its first vote in Congress Wednesday, an official said.
The government wants to extend the FEF for two-and-a-half years after June 30, when an existing version of the fund is due to expire.
The FEF allows the Treasury to hold on to about $10 billion annually from funds it is constitutionally obliged to pass on to states and muncipalities.
The government says it uses the FEF for social spending, avoiding the need for budget cuts or extra borrowing.

The Constitution and Justice Committee of the Chamber of Deputies was due to vote on the bill Wednesday morning, said a spokeswoman for Deputy Jose Luiz Clerot, who is in charge of the legislation's progress through the panel.
If approved, as expected, it would advance to another, special committee where lawmakers could seek to reduce the two-and-a-half-year extension period, the spokeswoman said.
As a constitutional amendment, the bill also requires two three-fifths majorities in each house of Congress.
